description: Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), H2 receptor antagonists, Antiemetics, Antidiarrheals, Laxatives, Antacids, Antiulcer agents, Bowel prep medications

questions.stem: A client taking omeprazole (Prilosec) for GERD should be instructed to:
options: Take with meals for best absorption
questions.rationale: PPIs like omeprazole should be taken 30-60 minutes before breakfast (or the first meal) for optimal acid suppression. They work best when taken consistently, not PRN. Take daily even without symptoms for healing.

questions.stem: Which laboratory value should be monitored in a client on long-term PPI therapy?
questions.rationale: Long-term PPI use can cause hypomagnesemia and decreased calcium absorption leading to osteoporosis and fracture risk. Also associated with vitamin B12 deficiency, C. difficile infection, and pneumonia risk.

questions.stem: A client taking ranitidine (Zantac) reports continued heartburn. Which instruction is appropriate?
options: Take the medication with antacids for better effect
Take 30 minutes to 1 hour before meals
Switch to taking it in the morning only
questions.rationale: H2 blockers like ranitidine work best when taken 30-60 minutes before meals to prevent acid production. May need to switch to a PPI if symptoms persist. Antacids can interfere with absorption.

questions.stem: A client with nausea is prescribed ondansetron (Zofran). Which adverse effect should the nurse monitor for?
questions.rationale: Ondansetron (5-HT3 antagonist) commonly causes headache and constipation. It can also prolong QT interval. Highly effective for chemotherapy-induced and postoperative nausea/vomiting.

questions.stem: Which medication is contraindicated with metoclopramide (Reglan)?
questions.rationale: Metoclopramide increases GI motility through prokinetic action. Anticholinergics decrease GI motility, counteracting its effects. Metoclopramide can also cause extrapyramidal symptoms and tardive dyskinesia with long-term use.

questions.stem: A client taking loperamide (Imodium) for diarrhea should be taught to:
options: Take it for no longer than 2 days without consulting provider
Take it indefinitely for chronic diarrhea
Expect it to work within 5 minutes
Take it with a laxative for balance
questions.rationale: Loperamide is for acute diarrhea; if symptoms persist beyond 48 hours, consult provider to rule out serious causes (infection, IBD). Prolonged use can cause toxic megacolon. Never use for bacterial diarrhea as it traps pathogens.

questions.stem: Which statement by a patient taking a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) indicates need for further teaching?
options: "I take this medication 30 minutes before breakfast."
"I can stop taking this as soon as my heartburn goes away."
"I should swallow the capsule whole, not crush it."
"This medication may take a few days to work fully."
questions.rationale: PPIs should be taken for the full prescribed course (typically 4-8 weeks) even if symptoms improve, to allow complete healing of esophageal damage. Stopping early can cause symptom relapse. Take 30-60 min before first meal, swallow whole (enteric-coated), and full effect takes 1-4 days.

questions.stem: A patient on long-term omeprazole (Prilosec) therapy is at increased risk for:
questions.rationale: Long-term PPI use (>1 year) increases fracture risk, especially hip, wrist, and spine fractures, due to decreased calcium absorption. Also causes hypomagnesemia (not hyper), vitamin B12 deficiency, increased C. difficile and pneumonia risk. Use lowest effective dose for shortest duration.

questions.stem: Which patient education is important for famotidine (Pepcid), an H2 blocker?
options: "Take this medication only when you have heartburn."
"Take 30-60 minutes before meals for prevention, or at bedtime."
"This medication works better than PPIs for severe GERD."
"You must take this on an empty stomach only."
questions.rationale: H2 blockers like famotidine are taken 30-60 minutes before meals to prevent acid secretion, or at bedtime for nighttime symptoms. They work faster than PPIs but are less potent. Often used for mild GERD or PRN symptom relief. Can be taken with or without food.

questions.stem: A patient taking metoclopramide (Reglan) for gastroparesis develops involuntary facial movements and tongue protrusion. The nurse recognizes this as:
options: Expected side effect that will resolve
questions.rationale: Metoclopramide can cause tardive dyskinesia (involuntary movements), especially with long-term use (>12 weeks) or in elderly/diabetic patients. This may be irreversible even after stopping the drug. Report immediately. It also causes extrapyramidal symptoms and depression. Use for shortest duration possible.

questions.stem: Which antiemetic is most commonly associated with prolonged QT interval on ECG?
questions.rationale: Ondansetron can prolong the QT interval, increasing risk of torsades de pointes, especially in patients with other risk factors (electrolyte imbalances, other QT-prolonging drugs). Monitor ECG in high-risk patients. Despite this, it's highly effective for chemotherapy-induced and postoperative nausea.

questions.stem: A chemotherapy patient asks which antiemetic class is most effective for preventing nausea. The nurse responds:
questions.rationale: 5-HT3 antagonists (ondansetron, granisetron, palonosetron) are the most effective class for chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. Often combined with dexamethasone and NK-1 antagonists for highly emetogenic chemo. Aprepitant (NK-1 antagonist) is also very effective.

questions.stem: Which medication is appropriate for acute treatment of diarrhea but contraindicated if infection is suspected?
questions.rationale: Loperamide slows intestinal motility and is effective for non-infectious diarrhea. However, it's contraindicated with infectious diarrhea (E. coli, Salmonella, C. difficile) because slowing motility traps pathogens and toxins, worsening infection and potentially causing toxic megacolon. Bismuth subsalicylate is safer with mild infectious diarrhea.

questions.stem: A patient with infectious diarrhea asks what they can take. Which medication is safest?
questions.rationale: Bismuth subsalicylate has mild antibacterial properties and can be used for infectious diarrhea (including traveler's diarrhea). Antimotility agents like loperamide and diphenoxylate are contraindicated in infectious diarrhea. Hydration and electrolyte replacement are the mainstays of treatment. Note: Bismuth causes black tongue/stools (harmless).

questions.stem: Which instruction is correct for a patient taking bisacodyl (Dulcolax), a stimulant laxative?
options: "Take this daily for chronic constipation prevention."
"Use for short-term relief only; long-term use causes dependence."
"Crush the tablets and mix with food for faster action."
questions.rationale: Stimulant laxatives (bisacodyl, senna) should be used short-term only. Long-term use can cause laxative dependence, electrolyte imbalances, and damage to intestinal nerves (cathartic colon). Swallow tablets whole; crushing defeats enteric coating and causes gastric irritation. Works in 6-12 hours (oral) or 15-60 min (suppository).

questions.stem: A patient asks which type of laxative is gentlest and safest for long-term use. The nurse responds:
questions.rationale: Bulk-forming laxatives (psyllium, methylcellulose) are the safest for long-term use. They work naturally by absorbing water and increasing stool bulk. Require adequate fluid intake (8 oz water per dose). Work in 12-72 hours. No tolerance develops. Stimulant laxatives cause dependence. Mineral oil decreases vitamin absorption.

questions.stem: Which instruction is essential for a patient starting psyllium (Metamucil)?
options: "Mix with at least 8 oz of water and drink additional fluids throughout the day."
questions.rationale: Bulk-forming laxatives MUST be taken with adequate fluids (at least 8 oz water) to prevent esophageal or intestinal obstruction. Inadequate fluid can cause choking or impaction. Increase daily water intake. Effects take 12-72 hours. Start with small doses and increase gradually to minimize gas/bloating.

questions.stem: Which laxative works the fastest and is commonly used for bowel prep before colonoscopy?
questions.rationale: High-dose osmotic laxatives (polyethylene glycol solutions like GoLYTELY, MiraLAX) work rapidly (1-3 hours) and are used for bowel preparation. They draw water into the colon. For chronic constipation, low-dose polyethylene glycol (MiraLAX) can be used long-term safely. Ensure adequate hydration.

questions.stem: A patient taking docusate (Colace) asks how it works. The nurse explains:
options: "It stimulates bowel contractions to move stool."
"It softens stool by allowing water and fat to mix with stool."
"It adds bulk to stool to stimulate peristalsis."
"It draws water into the intestines rapidly."
questions.rationale: Docusate is a stool softener (surfactant) that allows water and fats to penetrate stool, making it softer and easier to pass. It doesn't stimulate peristalsis. Gentle and safe for patients who should avoid straining (cardiac patients, hemorrhoids, postpartum). Takes 1-3 days to work. Often used with opioids.

questions.stem: Which patient is at highest risk for constipation and should receive prophylactic stool softeners?
questions.rationale: Opioids commonly cause constipation by decreasing GI motility. All patients on opioids should receive prophylactic bowel regimen (stool softener + stimulant laxative) from day one. Tolerance to this side effect doesn't develop. Methylnaltrexone is available for opioid-induced constipation resistant to laxatives.

questions.stem: A patient taking mineral oil for constipation should be taught:
options: "Take this medication with meals for better absorption."
"Avoid long-term use; it can decrease absorption of fat-soluble vitamins."
"This is the safest laxative for daily use."
"Mix with hot beverages for enhanced effect."
questions.rationale: Mineral oil is a lubricant laxative that softens stool but interferes with absorption of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K) and can cause lipid pneumonia if aspirated. Take on empty stomach (not with meals) and avoid long-term use. Not recommended for elderly or those with swallowing difficulties due to aspiration risk.

questions.stem: Which medication used for hepatic encephalopathy works by decreasing ammonia absorption?
questions.rationale: Lactulose is an osmotic laxative that acidifies the colon, trapping ammonia as ammonium ion and promoting its excretion through bowel movements. Goal is 2-3 soft bowel movements daily. Also used as a laxative. Can cause bloating, cramping. Rifaximin is another medication for hepatic encephalopathy.

questions.stem: A patient with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is prescribed sulfasalazine. Which instruction is important?
options: "This medication will cure your IBD permanently."
"Take with food and increase fluid intake; report any rash immediately."
"Expect your urine to turn bright green."
"Stop taking this as soon as symptoms improve."
questions.rationale: Sulfasalazine (5-ASA drug) reduces inflammation in IBD. Take with food and fluids. It can cause hypersensitivity reactions including rash (report immediately), GI upset, and rarely blood dyscrasias. Urine/skin may turn yellow-orange (harmless). Continue as prescribed even when asymptomatic to maintain remission. Folic acid supplementation recommended.

questions.stem: Which antiemetic is commonly used for motion sickness prevention?
questions.rationale: Meclizine is an antihistamine effective for motion sickness and vertigo. Take 1 hour before travel. Causes drowsiness. Scopolamine patch is also used for motion sickness. Ondansetron is for chemo/post-op nausea. Metoclopramide is a prokinetic agent.

questions.stem: A pregnant patient experiencing severe nausea asks which medication is safest. The nurse responds:
options: "Doxylamine-pyridoxine (vitamin B6) combination is FDA-approved for pregnancy nausea."
questions.rationale: Doxylamine-pyridoxine (Diclegis, Bonjesta) is FDA-approved for nausea/vomiting of pregnancy. Vitamin B6 alone or with doxylamine (sleep aid) is first-line. Non-pharmacologic measures (small frequent meals, ginger, acupressure) should also be tried. Ondansetron is used off-label for hyperemesis gravidarum when other treatments fail.

questions.stem: Which antacid should be avoided in patients with chronic kidney disease?
questions.rationale: Magnesium-containing antacids can cause hypermagnesemia in renal insufficiency. Aluminum-containing antacids can cause aluminum toxicity and constipation in CKD patients. Calcium carbonate is safer but can cause constipation and kidney stones. In CKD, PPIs or H2 blockers are preferred over antacids.

questions.stem: A patient asks about the difference between antacids and PPIs. The nurse explains:
options: "Antacids work faster but for shorter duration; PPIs take longer but provide 24-hour relief."
questions.rationale: Antacids neutralize existing stomach acid, working within minutes but lasting only 1-3 hours. Good for immediate symptom relief. PPIs block acid production, taking 1-4 days for full effect but providing up to 24-hour relief. PPIs are more potent and better for healing. H2 blockers fall in between: work in 30-60 min, last 4-10 hours.

questions.stem: Which side effect is common with aluminum-based antacids?
questions.rationale: Aluminum-based antacids (Maalox, Amphojel) cause constipation. Magnesium-based antacids cause diarrhea. Products often combine both to balance side effects. Calcium carbonate also causes constipation. Antacids can interfere with absorption of many medications; separate doses by 2 hours.

questions.stem: A patient with a history of H. pylori infection asks about treatment. Which regimen is correct?
options: Triple therapy: PPI + 2 antibiotics for 10-14 days
questions.rationale: H. pylori requires combination therapy: PPI (omeprazole) + 2 antibiotics (usually clarithromycin + amoxicillin OR metronidazole) for 10-14 days. Sometimes bismuth is added (quadruple therapy). Treat to eradicate infection and prevent ulcer recurrence, gastritis, and gastric cancer. Breath test confirms eradication 4 weeks after treatment.

questions.stem: Which patient education is important for someone taking sucralfate (Carafate) for peptic ulcer?
options: "Take this medication with meals for best effect."
"Take on empty stomach, 1 hour before meals and at bedtime."
"Mix this medication with milk for easier swallowing."
"This medication works by reducing acid production."
questions.rationale: Sucralfate creates a protective barrier over ulcers. Must be taken on empty stomach (1 hour before meals and at bedtime) for optimal adherence to damaged mucosa. Take with water only. It doesn't reduce acid; it protects tissue. Can cause constipation. Separate from other medications by 2 hours as it can interfere with absorption.
